questions.text: Which of the following layers is not present in the cardiac valve?
questions.solution:
Adventitia is not a layer of the cardiac valves. It is the outermost layer of a blood vessel. It contains connective tissue, a few cells, macrophages, mast cells, fibroblasts, and the nerves and vessels that supply the vascular wall.

Cardiac valves are lined by endothelium and share a tri-layered architecture:

  •  Fibrosa is a dense collagenous core at the outflow surface. It is connected to the valvular supporting structures.
  •  Spongiosa is a central core of loose connective tissue
  •  Ventricularis or atrialis is a layer rich in elastin on the inflow surface.

questions.text: You are conducting an autopsy of an elderly patient who was found dead in his home. Which of the following changes in the heart will not be suggestive of normal aging?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, an increase in the size of the left ventricle is not normally seen in the heart of an elderly person. The size of the left ventricular cavity is decreased in the aged heart, particularly in the base-to-apex dimension. This change is exacerbated by systemic hypertension.

Changes in the aging heart:

  1. Chambers: 
    • Increased left atrial cavity size
    • Decreased left ventricular cavity size
  2. Valves: 
    • Fibrous thickening of valve leaflets
    • Aortic and mitral valve calcific deposits
  3. Epicardial coronary arteries: 
    • Diminished compliance
    • Calcific deposits
    • Atherosclerotic plaques
  4. Myocardium: 
    • Increased subepicardial fat
    • Brown atrophy 
    • Lipofuscin deposition
    • Basophilic degeneration
    • Amyloid deposits
  5. Aorta:
    • Dilated with a rightward shift
    • Elastic fragmentation and collagen accumulation
    • Atherosclerotic plaque

questions.text: What type of cells are heart failure cells?
questions.solution:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin. 

The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure.

Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failure predominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormally stiff and cannot relax during diastole.

Causes of diastolic heart failure:

  • Hypertension: most common 
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Bilateral renal artery stenosis 

Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when the contractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause isolated right-sided heart failure?
questions.solution:
Isolated right-sided heart failure is not caused by left-sided heart failure.

Isolated right-sided heart failure is not common and usually occurs in patients with disorders affecting the lungs. Therefore, it is often referred to as cor pulmonale. It is caused by disorders of the lung parenchyma and pulmonary vasculature. It is also caused by conditions causing pulmonary vasoconstriction like obstructive sleep apnea and altitude sickness.

Pulmonary hypertension is the common feature of these disorders, which leads to hypertrophy and dilation of the right side of the heart.

Right-sided heart failure is most commonly caused by left-sided heart failure. This is because an increase in pressure in the pulmonary circulation from left-sided failure burdens the right side of the heart.

Related Pearl: Causes of CorPulmonale

CAUSES OF COR PULMONALE
Diseases of the Pulmonary Parenchyma

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis

Pneumoconioses

Cystic fibrosis

Bronchiectasis
Disorders of Chronic (Alveolar) Hypoxia

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

Central hypoventilation syndrome

Neuromuscular respiratory failure

Chest wall disorders - kyphoscoliosis 

Chronic exposure to high altitude
Diseases of the Pulmonary Vasculature

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)

  • Idiopathic
  • Heritable
  • Drug and toxin-induced
  • Veno-occlusive disease

Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension

Pulmonary tumor thrombotic microangiopathy

questions.text: A massive pulmonary embolism occurs in a patient with acute cor-pulmonale. What pathological changes do you expect in the heart of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has acute cor pulmonale. This causes right ventricular dilation without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle is transformed to a dilated ovoid.

In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens. The hypertrophied right ventricle may compress the left ventricular chamber. It can also cause regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.

questions.text: The liver specimen obtained after the autopsy of a patient is given below. What could be the likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestive hepatomegaly.  This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure.

In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the central veins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested and red-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liver appearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis.

Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venous hypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is known as congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of the bowel.

questions.text: Which hormone reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women of reproductive age?
questions.solution:
Estrogen reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women in the reproductive age group.

Accelerated coronary artery disease is associated with the postmenopausal decline in estrogen production. However, postmenopausal hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shown to be beneficial.

The most common cause of death in older women is ischemic heart disease.

Through middle age, males have a relatively increased risk of myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to the casualty with severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG showed ST-segment elevation in precordial leads. The person succumbed after 3 hours. On autopsy, the patient's heart was immersed in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. What colour would be imparted to the heart?

choices.text: Viable myocardium appears brick red and infarct appears pale
Viable myocardium appears red and infarct appears dark blue
Viable myocardium appears unstained and the infarct appears dark red

questions.solution:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick red colour to the viable non-infarcted myocardium. The infarct appears unstained and pale.

Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution.

The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.

The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

questions.text: What is the approximate time of onset of microvascular injury in ischemic cardiac myocytes?
questions.solution:
Microvascular injury begins >1 hour after the onset of ischemia.

Related Pearl: Approximate Time of onset of Key Events in Ischemic Cardiac Myocytes

Feature

Time

Onset of ATP depletion

Seconds

Loss of contractility

<2 minutes

ATP reduced

to 50% of normal

to 10% of normal

 

10 minutes

40 minutes

Irreversible cell injury

20-40 minutes

Microvascular injury

>1 hour

questions.text: What is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction.

Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electron microscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Time

Gross Features

Microscopy features

Reversible Injury

0-1/2 hr

None

EM: Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

LM: None

Irreversible Injury 

1/2-4 hr

None

EM: Sarcolemmal disruption; mitochondrial amorphous densities

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

4-12 hr

Dark mottling (occasional)

LM: Early coagulation necrosis, edema, hemorrhage

12-24 hr

Dark mottling

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct center

LM: Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations, brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Hyperemic border, central yellow-tan softening

LM: Begining disintegration of dead myofibres, with dying neutrophils, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border

7-10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft with depressed red-tan margins

LM: Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Red-grey depressed infarct borders

LM: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 wk

Grey-white scar, progressive from the  border towards the core of the infarct

LM: increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 mo

Scarring complete

LM: Dense collagenous scar

EM: Electron microscopy

LM: Light microscopy

questions.text: You are conducting the autopsy of a patient who passed away following myocardial infarction. What would be the earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient?
questions.solution:
The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct.

These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.

Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.

The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.

questions.text: Following myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis begins at?
questions.solution:
Early coagulative necrosis begins in myocardial infarction by 4–12 hours.

However, it is prominent between 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction.

questions.text: The heart of a patient who had suffered a myocardial infarction is subjected to a histopathological examination. The microscopic image is given below. What time following infarction would you observe this?
questions.solution:
The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltration starts by 12–24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a light microscope.

The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3 days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.

The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.

questions.text: A patient was admitted four days back following acute myocardial infarction. What type of cells would you expect to see in the infarcted area in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, 4 days after MI, macrophages are seen in the infarcted area.

They phagocytose dead myocytes at the border of the infarct earliest by 72 hours. Removal of the necrotic myocytes is most noticeable by 3 to 7 days.

The image below shows a macrophagic infiltrate in the infarcted area.

questions.text:
Match the following:

Morphological

features

Time

1) Well established

granulation

a) 12 - 24 hours

2) Complete scarring

b) 1 - 3 days

3) Myocyte hypereosinophilia

c) 10 - 14 days

4) Grey white scar

d) 2 - 8 weeks

5) Loss of nuclei and

striations

 

e) > 2 months
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  • Well established granulation - 10 - 14 days
  • Complete scarring - > 2 months
  • Myocyte hypereosinophilia - 12 - 24 hours
  • Grey white scar - 2-8 weeks
  • Loss of nuclei and striations - 1 - 3 days

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is found dead in her home. On autopsy, hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture is seen. How long before her death did she probably have a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
The given autopsy finding of hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture occurs most frequently 3-7 days after myocardial infarction (MI). During this time, the lysis of the necrotic myocardium is maximum.  Thus most of the infarct has been converted to friable granulation tissue.

The risk factors for free-wall rupture are:

  • Age > 60 years 
  • Female gender 
  • First MI 
  • Large, transmural and anterior MI 
  • Absence of left ventricular hypertrophy 
  • Preexisting hypertension

It is less frequent in patients with prior MI because associated fibrotic scarring inhibits myocardial tearing. 

Complications of MI:

  1. Heart failure - 
    • This is due to ventricular dysfunction caused by the infarct and ventricular remodeling
    • Usually occurs within a day
  2. Cardiogenic shock - 
    • This is usually seen in severe multivessel coronary artery disease due to extensive involvement of myocardium
    • Usually occurs within a day
  3. Arrhythmias - most common complication, occurring usually 2 days after infarction
    • Most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI - ventricular fibrillation
    • Most common arrhythmia after one hour of MI - supraventricular tachycardia 
  4. Myocardial rupture - occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. It includes the following - 
    • Left ventricular free wall rupture (most common) - leads to cardiac tamponade
    • Interventricular septal rupture - leads acute ventricular septal defect (VSD)
    • Papillary muscle rupture - leads to severe mitral regurgitation
  5. Mitral regurgitation (MR) - this can occur due to -
    • Transient papillary muscle dysfunction - mid-systolic or late-systolic murmur
    • Rupture of papillary muscle - pansystolic murmur 
  6. Dressler syndrome (post-MI syndrome) - 
    • This is an immune-mediated reaction and presents as pericarditis, pleurisy, and fever 
    • It can occur even 48 hrs after MI but usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI and often subside after a few days
  7. Ventricular aneurysm
  8. Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus

questions.text: What causes tigered myocardium?
questions.solution: Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fatty change. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating with normal myocardium.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the maximum damage in reperfusion injury?
questions.solution:
In reperfusion injury, the maximum damage is caused by free radicals.

Reperfusion is the restoration of blood flow to the ischemic myocardium threatened by infarction. Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. Once the flow is restored, there is bleeding.

On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.

Reperfusion injury may be mediated by: 

  • Oxidative stress
  • Calcium overload 
  • Inflammatory cells recruited after tissue reperfusion

questions.text: What creatine kinase isoenzymes do the heart muscle contain?
questions.solution:
Heart muscle contains MM and MB isoenzymes of creatine kinase.

Creatine kinase (CK) has three isoenzymes:

  • CK-1 (BB) - brain, nerve tissue, prostate (small amounts), intestine, lung, bladder, kidney, uterus, thyroid
  • CK-2 (MB) - heart and skeletal muscle
  • CK-3 (MM) - skeletal and heart muscle

Elevation of the CK-MB isoforms is seen in MI. CK-MB is less sensitive and less specific, therefore, troponins are preferred for the diagnosis of MI. CK-MB begins to rise within 3-12 hours of the onset of MI. It peaks at about 24 hours and returns to normal within approximately 48-72 hours.

questions.text: A patient comes to the hospital after 3 hours of the onset of chest pain. ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads. Which of the following enzymes would be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI). Enzymes elevated after 4 to 8 hours of MI are CK-MB (creatine kinase MB) and troponins. 

When cardiac troponin is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI. If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and less specific.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnoea. His wife reports that he had chest pain 7 days back which had lasted for 2 days. You suspect that the patient's chest pain was due to myocardial infarction. If so, blood levels of which of the following enzymes would be elevated now?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, on post-MI day 7, troponin and LDH will be raised. Troponins are highly specific for MI and remain elevated for 7 to 10 days.

Troponins are proteins that regulate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles. It is the single biomarker preferred for diagnosing MI, late diagnosis of MI, and diagnosis of reinfarction. Troponin I is more important than troponin T.

Cardiac troponin increases rapidly in patients with reinfarction. Sometimes, the cardiac troponin concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. Then the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement. 

Myoglobin is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI. It is a protein that is found in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen. It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury. But it is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle. Myoglobin and SGOT levels come to baseline before day 1.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: The blood levels of various cardiac biomarkers are measured in a patient following myocardial infarction. This is represented in the given graph. Which biomarker does the yellow curve depict?
questions.solution:
The yellow curve here shows the levels of CK-MB which starts rising around 4 to 8 hrs post-MI, peaks at 24 hours and becomes normal at 48 to 72 hrs.

The post-myocardial infarction blood levels of the different cardiac biomarkers are shown in the image given below.

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: Loss-of-function mutation in potassium channel gene KCNQ1 results in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Loss of function mutation in K+ channel genes KCNQ1 and KCNH2 produces the long QT syndrome. The gain-of-function mutation produces the short QT syndrome.

Long QT syndrome manifests as arrhythmias associated with excessive prolongation of cardiac repolarization. Stress-induced syncope or sudden cardiac death (SCD), are common presentations.

Short QT syndrome presents with arrhythmias associated with abbreviated repolarization intervals. They also present with palpitations, syncope, and SCD.

Brugada syndrome manifests as ECG abnormalities like ST-segment elevations and right bundle-branch block. This occurs in the absence of structural heart disease. Here, patients classically present with syncope or SCD during rest or sleep or after large meals.

Familial atrial fibrillation is caused by a gain of function mutation in genes coding potassium channels.

questions.text: What is the most common mechanism behind sudden cardiac death?
questions.solution:
The mechanism behind sudden cardiac death (SCD) is most often a lethal arrhythmia, e.g., asystole or ventricular fibrillation.

Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for 80% to 90% of cases. But, the mechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia. Infarction need not occur. Most of the patients who have SCD but are successfully resuscitated do not show any enzymatic or ECG evidence of myocardial necrosis.

Ischemic injury can directly affect the major components of the conduction system. But, most cases of fatal arrhythmia are triggered by electrical irritability of the myocardium.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions have an increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease?
questions.solution:
Patients with hyperlipidemia have an increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease (CAD).

Hyperlipidemia is considered the second most common risk factor for CAD worldwide after hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia was implicated in 55% of cases with combined hyperlipidemia in 41% cases.

questions.text: What is lipoprotein a [Lp (a)] composed of?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein A (apo A). It is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

Increased Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk. It is independent of total cholesterol or LDL levels.

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium:
questions.solution:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.

During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils after reperfusion. 

On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.

Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.

Related Pearl: The Temporal Evolution of the Morphologic Changes in Acute MI

Time

Gross Features

Microscopy features

Reversible Injury

0-1/2 hr

None

EM: Relaxation of myofibrils; glycogen loss; mitochondrial swelling

LM: None

Irreversible Injury 

1/2-4 hr

None

EM: Sarcolemmal disruption; mitochondrial amorphous densities

LM: Usually none; variable waviness of fibers at border

4-12 hr

Dark mottling (occasional)

LM: Early coagulation necrosis, edema, hemorrhage

12-24 hr

Dark mottling

LM: Ongoing coagulation necrosis, pyknosis of nuclei, myocyte hypereosinophilia, marginal contraction band necrosis, early neutrophilic infiltrate

1-3 days

Mottling with yellow-tan infarct center

LM: Coagulation necrosis, with loss of nuclei and striations, brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils

3-7 days

Hyperemic border, central yellow-tan softening

LM: Begining disintegration of dead myofibres, with dying neutrophils, early phagocytosis of dead cells by macrophages at the infarct border

7-10 days

Maximally yellow-tan and soft with depressed red-tan margins

LM: Well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells; granulation tissue at margins

10-14 days

Red-grey depressed infarct borders

LM: Well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition

2-8 wk

Grey-white scar, progressive from the  border towards the core of the infarct

LM: increased collagen deposition, with decreased cellularity

>2 mo

Scarring complete

LM: Dense collagenous scar

EM: Electron microscopy

LM: Light microscopy
